pageData.text: This investigation explores <button class='glossary-text'>condensation reactions</button>, which are common in organic chemistry. In activity 1, you will use this reaction to synthesize fragrant esters and analyze their smell. In activity 2, you will synthesize the polyamide, nylon-6,10.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 10 minutes
Activity 1: Synthesis of Aromatic Esters - 30 minutes
Activity 2: Synthesis of Nylon - 10 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 10 minutes
Activity 1: Synthesis of Aromatic Esters - 30 minutes
Activity 2: Synthesis of Nylon - 10 minutes

Predict the reaction products for several <button class='glossary-text'>condensation reactions</button>.
Analyze the smell of different esters.
Determine the names of various esters.
Understand the role of a catalyst in chemical reactions
Describe the formation of a <button class='glossary-text'>polymer</button>.

pageData.text: Esters are commonly used in products where a pleasant smell is the goal, such as perfumes and colognes, and are often described as fruity. The fragrant nature of esters is due to their high volatility, which is influenced by weak intermolecular forces. This allows ester molecules to break away from their source and, in this case, enter our noses to be received by olfactory receptors that line the nose. Specifically, these receptors have hair-like projections called cilia that bind to odorants, such as esters. Each of the receptors in the nose is encoded by a specific gene and each recognizes a different odorant.

Esters are found naturally in fruits or flowers. For example, ethyl ethanoate contributes to the smell we associate with pineapples, isoamyl acetate we associate with bananas, 3-methylbutyl-3-methylbutanoate we associate with apples, and octyl acetate we associate with oranges. As we identify the sources of these fragrances, scientists can then mimic them in artificial flavorings.

pageData.desc: Three dark glass vials on a table with an arrangement of citrus slices, herb sprigs and spices.
pageData.altText: Three dark glass vials on a table with an arrangement of citrus slices, herb sprigs and spices.

pageData.text: What do the scent of an apple and parachute fabric have in common? Both contain chemicals that result from a common organic chemistry reaction, the <button class='glossary-text'>condensation reaction</button>. This type of reaction is named this way because a small molecule, usually water, is one of the products.

The acid-catalyzed condensation reaction between a carboxylic acid and an alcohol yields an ester. Thus, this type of condensation reaction is an esterification. The following reaction shows an esterification.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A reaction diagram shows an alcohol, R prime O H, adding to a carboxylic acid, R C O O H. The products are an ester, R C O O R prime, and water

pageData.text: R and R' are hydrocarbon sections of various lengths and composition.
The following page describes an advanced analysis of the mechanism of this reaction.

pages.title: Appendix 1
pages.pageTitle: Appendix 1. The Reaction Mechanism of an Esterification Condensation Reaction.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: The reaction mechanism of an esterification condensation reaction

pageData.text: The esterification reaction is an acid-catalyzed nucleophilic substitution reaction at the acyl carbon atom. In the first step, the organic acid accepts a proton from the catalyst, a strong acid. The alcohol then attacks the protonated carbonyl group forming an intermediate. A proton is lost at one oxygen and gained at the other. Then, a molecule of water is shed from the intermediate, giving a protonated ester. Finally, the proton transfers to a base, leaving the ester.

Esters can have a wide variety of pleasant smells as described in Table 1. Most fruits and flowers derive their fragrance, in part, from ester compounds, and many esters are synthesized for use in perfumes, as food additives, and in cosmetics. In addition to use as a fragrance, some esters also increase the shelf life of cosmetic products.

tableData.text: CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>(CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>)<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>CO<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>

CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>(CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>)<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>CO<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>(CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>)<sub class='bodysubscript'>5</sub>CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>

CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>(CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>)<sub class='bodysubscript'>5</sub>CO<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>CH<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>

pageData.question: Esterification, or the condensation reaction that produces an ester, involves what two types of reactants?

options.text: a carboxylic acid and an alcohol
a phenol and a weak acid

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The acid-catalyzed condensation reaction between a carboxylic acid and an alcohol yields an ester.

pageData.question: Which of the following properties makes esters easy to identify?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Esters can have a wide variety of distinctive smells, which makes them easy to identify without laboratory equipment.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The acid-catalyzed condensation reaction between a carboxylic acid and an alcohol yields an ester. Thus, this type of condensation reaction is an esterification. Condensation reactions can not only produce esters, which often have distinctive smells, but also compounds used to make synthetic textiles, such as parachute fabric.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The acid-catalyzed condensation reaction between a carboxylic acid and an alcohol yields an ester. Thus, this type of condensation reaction is an esterification. Condensation reactions can not only produce esters, which often have distinctive smells, but also compounds used to make synthetic textiles, such as parachute fabric.

pageData.text: The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) has standardized the rules for naming esters. Ester names derive from the length of the R groups on either side of the ester functional group. The alcohol component of an ester serves as the first part of the name. For example, ethanol, which has two carbon atoms, would provide ethyl as this first portion. The carboxyl component of an ester serves as the last part of the name. To name the carboxyl component, replace the “ic acid” part of the name with “ate.” For example, the heptanoic acid component of an ester would be altered to heptanoate. Therefore, the ester formed from the condensation of ethanol and heptanoic acid would be ethyl heptanoate.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A line drawing of ethyl heptanoate, which has the formula C H 3, C H 2, O, C double bond O, C H 2, C H 2, C H 2, C H 2, C H 2, C H 3

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Condensation reactions</button> are not limited to alcohols reacting with carboxylic acids. When an amine reacts with a carboxylic acid, the condensation reaction between the two yields an amide. The following reaction shows an amidification. R and R’ are hydrocarbon sections of various lengths and composition.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: A reaction diagram shows an amine, R prime N H two, adding to a carboxylic acid, R C O O H. The products are an amide, R C O N R prime, and water. The reaction is reversible

pageData.question: The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry’s (IUPAC) rules for naming esters are based on which of the following properties of an ester’s structure?

options.text: the length of the R groups on either side of the ester functional group
the number of R groups bonded to the ester functional group
the length of the molecule and the presence or absence of a carboxylic acid group
the length of the molecule only
the position of the ester functional group and the presence or absence of a hydroxyl group

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Ester names derive from the length of the R groups on either side of the ester functional group.

pageData.question: An esterification condensation reaction between methanol and ethanoic acid would produce which of the following esters, according to IUPAC naming conventions?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The alcohol component of an ester serves as the first part of the name. To name the carboxyl component, replace the “ic acid” part of the name with “ate.” The esterification of methanol and ethanoic acid yields the ester methyl ethanoate.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Since ester functional groups occur within an organic compound, as opposed to occurring at the beginning or end of an organic compound, these functional groups have hydrocarbon chains on either side. The lengths of these hydrocarbon chains are what separates one ester compound from another. Ester names, as defined by The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), derive from the length of the R groups on either side of the ester functional group. The alcohol component of an ester serves as the first part of the name.  The carboxyl component of an ester serves as the last part of the name. To name the carboxyl component, replace the “ic acid” part of the name with “ate.”

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Since ester functional groups occur within an organic compound, as opposed to occurring at the beginning or end of an organic compound, these functional groups have hydrocarbon chains on either side. The lengths of these hydrocarbon chains are what separates one ester compound from another. Ester names, as defined by The International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), derive from the length of the R groups on either side of the ester functional group. The alcohol component of an ester serves as the first part of the name.  The carboxyl component of an ester serves as the last part of the name. To name the carboxyl component, replace the “ic acid” part of the name with “ate.”

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will synthesize nylon-6,10 via a polymerization <button class='glossary-text'>condensation reaction</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Polymers</button> consist of long chains of repeating chemical units called monomers. In fact, the word polymer comes from the Greek words, polús (many) and meros (parts). The “6,10” designation relates to the number of carbon atoms in each monomer. In the case of nylon-6,10, the amine has six carbon atoms and the acid has ten. Commercially, nylon synthesis is conducted via a condensation reaction between a diacid and a diamine to form a polyamide. Figure 4 shows the synthesis of nylon-6,10.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: A reaction diagram shows the synthesis of nylon six, ten. The reaction reads hexemethylenediamine plus sebacic acid yields nylon six, ten, plus water

pageData.text: The following page describes an advanced analysis of the mechanism of this reaction.

Nylon is such a ubiquitous material in our lives owing to its mechanical strength and its ability to form fibers. Clothes, luggage, stockings, and electrical insulators are only a few examples of items constructed of nylon. Interestingly, the nylon synthesized in this activity is the material used in toothbrush bristles. Figure 5 shows the reaction that we will use to make nylon-6,10 in this lab.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: A reaction diagram shows the synthesis of nylon six, ten. The reaction reads hexemethylenediamine plus sebacoyl chloride yields nylon six, ten, plus hydrochloric acid

pages.title: Appendix 2
pages.pageTitle: Appendix 2. The Reaction Mechanism of an Amidification Condensation Reaction.

pageData.text: This is a simple nucleophilic substitution at the acyl carbon and progresses very much in the same way as the esterification reaction. Note that this mechanism occurs on both ends of each molecule in polyamide synthesis.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: The reaction mechanism of an amidification condensation reaction

pageData.question: Polymers such as nylon-6,10 are typically formed by a condensation reaction between what two types of reactants?

options.text: a carboxylic acid and an amine
an alcohol and a carboxylic acid

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When an amine reacts with a carboxylic acid, the condensation reaction between the two yields an amide.

pageData.question: Condensation reactions produce a small molecule, usually water, as a byproduct of the reaction. In the reaction you will use to synthesize nylon-6,10 in Activity 2, which molecule is a byproduct?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Because sebacoyl chloride is used instead of sebacic acid to synthesize nylon-6,10, hydrochloric acid is produced rather than water as a byproduct of the reaction.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Nylon is such a ubiquitous material in our lives owing to its mechanical strength and its ability to form fibers. Interestingly, the nylon synthesized in this investigation is the material used in toothbrush bristles. When an amine reacts with a carboxylic acid, the condensation reaction between the two yields an amide, as shown in Figure 4. In Activity 2, you will synthesize the polyamide nylon-6,10 via a polymerization condensation reaction using sebacoyl chloride rather than sebacic acid to synthesize nylon-6,10.

pageData.desc: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. Before beginning the activity, set up a heat-resistant work surface. Begin activity 1 by labeling 12 test tubes. Next, add sulfuric acid to each test tube. Then, add ethanoic acid to the test tubes labeled E A, add propanoic acid to tubes labeled P A, and add butanoic acid to tubes labeled BA. Then, add ethanol to tubes labeled / E, add propanol to tubes labeled / P, add 1-butanol to tubes labeled / B, and add 3-methyl-1-butanol to tubes labeled / 3. Next, incubate all test tubes in a hot water bath for 5 minutes, then observe the scent of each solution. Finally, determine the IUPAC name of each synthesized ester. To begin activity 2, create a paper clip hook. Then, add hexamethylene diamine to a test tube. Next, layer sebacoyl chloride on top of the amine solution. Finally, collect the nylon product from the test tube.
pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. Before beginning the activity, set up a heat-resistant work surface. Begin activity 1 by labeling 12 test tubes. Next, add sulfuric acid to each test tube. Then, add ethanoic acid to the test tubes labeled E A, add propanoic acid to tubes labeled P A, and add butanoic acid to tubes labeled BA. Then, add ethanol to tubes labeled / E, add propanol to tubes labeled / P, add 1-butanol to tubes labeled / B, and add 3-methyl-1-butanol to tubes labeled / 3. Next, incubate all test tubes in a hot water bath for 5 minutes, then observe the scent of each solution. Finally, determine the IUPAC name of each synthesized ester. To begin activity 2, create a paper clip hook. Then, add hexamethylene diamine to a test tube. Next, layer sebacoyl chloride on top of the amine solution. Finally, collect the nylon product from the test tube.

pageData.text: Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practice, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Ethanoic acid, propanoic acid, butanoic acid, ethanol, propanol, butanol, 3-methyl-1-butanol, sebacoyl chloride, and hexamethylene diamine are flammable. Keep these chemicals away from any heat or flame sources.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Sulfuric acid, ethanoic acid, propanoic acid, butanoic acid, propanol, butanol, sebacoyl chloride and hexamethylene diamine are corrosive materials. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes.
pageData.altText: corrosion symbol

pageData.text: Sulfuric acid, propanoic acid, ethanol, and sebacoyl chloride can cause organ damage if ingested. Keep away from food sources.
pageData.altText: health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Butanoic acid and ethanol may be  toxic if they make contact with skin. Butanoic acid may be toxic if ingested.
pageData.altText: toxic symbol

pageData.text: Propanol, butanol, sebacoyl chloride, and hexamethylene diamine are health hazards. Butanol, sebacoyl chloride and hexamethylene diamine are potential respiratory tract irritants. Propanol, butanol, 3-methyl-1-butanol and hexamethylene diamine may be harmful if ingested.
pageData.altText: warning symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Sulfuric acid is a strong acid. Should any spill, pour a solution of baking soda and water onto the spill to neutralize the acid. The acid is neutralized when the baking soda solution no longer “fizzes” when pouring atop the acid. The area can be wiped up with paper towels, and the paper towels discarded in the trash.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Butanoic acid is not hazardous, but it produces a strong, unpleasant smell. Use in a well-ventilated area or outside if possible.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area thoroughly with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: This investigation should be completed outside, or in a well-ventilated area, for which of the following reasons?

options.text: The butanoic acid in this investigation has a strong, unpleasant smell.
The ethanoic acid in this investigation produces hazardous fumes.
The sulfuric acid in this investigation is toxic if inhaled.
This investigation involves heating water over an open flame.
This investigation involves igniting organic compounds with an open flame.

options.text: an organic acid and an alcohol
an amine and an organic acid
an ether and a weak base

assestmentData.question: Esterification is which of the following types of reactions?
Which of the following best describes a polymer?

a molecule made from an acid-catalyzed reaction
a molecule that exists temporarily during a chemical reaction

assestmentData.question: Sulfuric acid is a strong acid. Which of the following best describes the proper action to take should any sulfuric acid spill during the investigation?

options.text: Neutralize the spill with a baking soda solution before wiping it up.
Immediately call a poison control center.
Cover the spill with a 10% bleach solution for 20 minutes before wiping it up.
Allow the spill to air dry before wiping it up with a wet paper towel.
Soak up the spill with wood shavings and discard the shavings in the trash.

assestmentData.question: Several of the materials in this investigation are corrosive. Which of the following steps should be taken if corrosive material contacts your skin or eyes?

options.text: Rinse the affected area with running water for at least 15 minutes.
Cover the affected area with baking soda until any pain subsides.
Open any windows in the room or turn on a fan.
Alternate applying cold packs and hot packs to the affected area every 15 minutes.

Read the entire procedure before beginning the activity.
Clear a work area for all lab materials. Your work area must be well-ventilated and away from pets and children.
Part of the work area should include a heat-resistant surface, such as a stovetop or trivet, because the beaker will contain hot water.
In Activity 1, you will synthesize aromatic esters using sulfuric acid as a catalyst. For each ester, you will observe its smell and provide its IUPAC name.

pages.title: Synthesis of Aromatic Esters (15 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Synthesis of Aromatic Esters (15 steps)

pageData.text: Label 12 test tubes: EA/E, EA/P, EA/B, EA/3, PA/E, PA/P, PA/B, PA/3, BA/E, BA/P, BA/B, and BA/3.
Place the labeled test tubes in the test tube rack.
Add 3 drops of 5 M sulfuric acid in each test tube.
Add 5 drops of ethanoic acid in each of the four test tubes labeled “EA.”
Add 5 drops of propanoic acid in each of the four test tubes labeled “PA.”
Add 5 drops of butanoic acid in each of the four test tubes labeled “BA.”
Caution: Butanoic acid produces a strong, unpleasant smell. Complete this step in a well-ventilated area or outdoors.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Add 10 drops of ethanol in each of the three test tubes labeled “/E.”
Add 10 drops of propanol in each of the three test tubes labeled “/P.”
Add 10 drops of 1-butanol in each of the three test tubes labeled “/B.”
Add 10 drops of 3-methyl-1-butanol in each of the three test tubes labeled “/3.”
Heat water either on a stovetop or in the microwave. The water does not need to be boiling but should be at least 70 ºC (158 ºF).
Caution: When handling the hot water, be cautious and use a heat-resistant glove or oven mitt.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Pour the hot water into the beaker a quarter to a third of the maximum volume.
Add all 12 test tubes to the hot water bath by first removing each test tube from the test tube rack and swirling to mix the contents. Let sit for at least 5 minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: After 5 minutes, remove each test tube from the water bath with a test tube clamp, swirl, and then waft the scent toward your nose. Do not hold the test tube close to your nose to smell, rather hold the test tube away from you and use your hand to fan the scent toward you as shown in Figure 8. Record each scent in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
Figure 8: A young woman in a white lab coat safely conducting a smell and odor test in a laboratory by holding the tube away from her face and fanning the odor toward her nose.

pageData.text: Determine names for each ester synthesized in this activity. Record the names in Data Table 1.
In Activity 2, you will synthesize the <button class='glossary-text'>polymer</button> nylon-6,10.
Straighten a jumbo paper clip and bend one end into a small hook as shown in Figure 9.

pageData.altText: Figure 9: Example of straightened paper clip with hook end

pageData.text: Use a pipet to add 4 mL of hexamethylene diamine into a clean test tube.
Tilt the test tube and use another pipet to slowly add 4 mL of sebacoyl chloride to the same test tube. Sebacoyl chloride is less dense than the amine solution, so it will be the top fraction.
Place this test tube in a beaker to hold the test tube upright, being sure to pay attention to the interface between the two liquids.
Use the bent paper clip to snag the nylon formed at the solution interface. The nylon is the white solid.

Slowly lift the paper clip out of the test tube to remove the nylon from the test tube. Rotate the paper clip so the nylon strand wraps around the hooked portion. Observe the continued synthesis at the interface of the two solutions.
Rinse the nylon strand with plenty of water and unwind it from the paper clip before taking a photograph of the strand.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: When no more nylon forms at the interface, vigorously swirl the test tube to ensure the reagents remaining in the solutions react.

text: Dispose of the leftover chemicals and chemical products of these activities immediately after completing the investigation.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>

pageData.text: The contents of the test tubes and leftover chemicals from Activity 1 may be discarded down a sink with plenty of running water. Let the water run for at least 30 seconds after disposal.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: To dispose of the leftover chemicals from Activity 2, repeat the activity procedure to combine the remainder of each solution in a clean test tube. Follow Step 8 from Activity 2 to make sure all the solution reacts. The nylon product can then be disposed of in the trash.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Wash and dry all reusable labware and return to the equipment kit.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Clean and sanitize the work space.

This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. Before beginning the activity, set up a heat-resistant work surface. Begin activity 1 by labeling 12 test tubes. Next, add sulfuric acid to each test tube. Then, add ethanoic acid to the test tubes labeled E A, add propanoic acid to tubes labeled P A, and add butanoic acid to tubes labeled BA. Then, add ethanol to tubes labeled / E, add propanol to tubes labeled / P, add 1-butanol to tubes labeled / B, and add 3-methyl-1-butanol to tubes labeled / 3. Next, incubate all test tubes in a hot water bath for 5 minutes, then observe the scent of each solution. Finally, determine the IUPAC name of each synthesized ester. To begin activity 2, create a paper clip hook. Then, add hexamethylene diamine to a test tube. Next, layer sebacoyl chloride on top of the amine solution. Finally, collect the nylon product from the test tube.
Figure 8: A young woman in a white lab coat safely conducting a smell and odor test in a laboratory by holding the tube away from her face and fanning the odor toward her nose.
Figure 9: Example of straightened paper clip with hook end

data.title: Condensation reaction
data.content: A type of chemical reaction in which a small molecule, usually water, is one of the products

data.title: Polymer
data.content: A molecule made up of long chains of repeating chemical units called monomers
